# Observing Semantic Change with Word Embeddings

Semantic change refers to how a word's meaning changes over time. Although semantic change is very complex, nuanced, and largely not well-suited to analytic manipulation, the availability of large, decade-spanning corpora of publications has allowed NLP researchers the opportunity to explore computational approaches to better observe it. In this post, I will provide a low-level introduction to using word embeddings as a conduit for observing semantic change.

### What is a Word Embedding?

A word embedding is an attempt to reduce the meaning and contextual use of a word to coordinates in an n-dimensional space, where dimensions represent abstracted semantic attributes for predicting/generating language (usually learned by a neural network).

Some of the state-of-the-art algorithms for generating word embeddings given a corpus include **word2vec**, **GloVe**, and **fastText**.

Another noteworthy embedding approach for observing semantic shift is [SensEmbed](https://aclanthology.org/P15-1010.pdf).

### Word Embedding as a Tool to Observe Semantic Change

Since the nearest neighbors of a word vector within a model represent the words that have the closest semantic essence to the target word (in terms of the neural network's abstracted paradigm of language generation), a word embedding's nearest neighbors can paint a semantic portrait of the word. Simply considering the nearest neighbors of each time period without attempting to align the coordinate systems of the different models is certainly the lowest hanging fruit for providing insightful clues about the how and why of semantic change.

To create mathematical comparisons between different neural models however, one must align the resultant coordinate systems using an alignment method such as [orthogonal Procrustes](https://nlp.stanford.edu/projects/histwords/). From there, measures of distance/similarity such as cosine similarity or Minkowski distance can be used to quantify semantic similarity/change over time.

The following are two-dimensional representations of semantic change using word embeddings found in [this paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1703.00607.pdf).

![](data:image/png;base64,)

![](data:image/png;base64,)

### Necessary Considerations

Before setting off to capture and understand the semantic change of your favorite words with these methods, one must consider inherent methodological limitations as well as other considerations including but not limited to:

 - The necessity for large amounts of training data
 - Word embeddings can vary greatly given changes in model hyperparameters
 - Orthogonal Procrustes and other coordinate alignment methods introduce certain deficiencies such as not being able to introduce new words that arise at later times
 - Typical sate-of-the-art word embeddings struggle with Polysemy (the coexistence of different senses within a single word)
 - Other statistical phenomena observed within the context of semantic change such as [the law of conformity and the law of innovation](https://aclanthology.org/P15-1010.pdf).

### Conclusion

My personal opinion is that using word embeddings to provide the entire narrative of the semantic change of a word is an impossibility. Nonetheless, I believe that word embeddings, when trained well, can provide invaluable and otherwise unavailable clues for elucidating how and why a word has changed or might possibly change in its associations and meanings.
